stem: The patient is exhibiting signs and symptoms related to autonomic dysreflexia. Based on the provided information in the patient's chart, indicate which interventions are appropriate or inappropriate for each clinical manifestation.

itemContext.sbar: Situation: John Smith, a 35-year-old male with a T6 spinal cord injury sustained three years ago, was admitted to the ICU for a sudden, significant increase in blood pressure. Background: The patient reports experiencing a severe, throbbing headache and blurred vision. He is exhibiting diaphoresis above the level of his injury and also reports nasal congestion. At 0600, the patient voided 100mL of clear urine. At 0700, his blood pressure was measured at 210/110 mmHg, with a heart rate of 50 bpm. He is also complaining of feeling increasingly anxious and restless. Assessment: Autonomic dysreflexia is suspected due to the constellation of symptoms and patient history. Possible triggers being investigated include bowel impaction, urinary retention, and the presence of any pressure ulcers. Recent lab results and medication administration records are accessible in the electronic health record (EHR). Recommendation: A STAT rectal exam is recommended to check for fecal impaction. A bladder scan should be performed immediately to rule out urinary retention. Administer nifedipine 10mg sublingually (SL) as a PRN medication. Continuously monitor blood pressure every 5 minutes. Immediately elevate the head of the bed to 90 degrees to help lower blood pressure. Further investigation into potential skin breakdown is also warranted.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Scheduled: Docusate sodium 100mg PO daily, Baclofen 20mg PO TID. PRN: Nifedipine 10mg SL for BP >180/100 mmHg, PRN: Acetaminophen 650mg PO q4h for headache.

tabs.content: 0600: BP 140/80 mmHg, HR 72 bpm, RR 16, SpO2 98% on room air. 0700: BP 210/110 mmHg, HR 50 bpm, RR 18, SpO2 99% on room air, Temp 98.6 F (37 C).

topicTags: Neurological: Spinal Cord Injury & Autonomic Dysreflexia

rationale.correct: Elevating the head of bed to 90 degrees helps to lower blood pressure by promoting venous pooling. Checking for bladder distention is crucial as urinary retention is a common trigger for autonomic dysreflexia. Administering nifedipine, a calcium channel blocker, helps to lower blood pressure rapidly. Performing a rectal exam to check for impaction is essential as bowel impaction is another common trigger. Monitoring blood pressure every 5 minutes allows for close observation of the patient's response to interventions. Loosening tight clothing helps to remove any external stimuli that could be contributing to the dysreflexia.
rationale.incorrect: Administering a fluid bolus is contraindicated as it can further elevate blood pressure. Lowering the head of bed will increase blood return to the heart, potentially worsening hypertension. Encouraging the patient to lie flat will increase blood pressure. Delaying the rectal exam could prolong the episode of autonomic dysreflexia and lead to complications. Decreasing frequency of blood pressure monitoring could result in delayed intervention. Leaving tight clothing in place may exacerbate the trigger.
clinicalPearls: Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency requiring prompt recognition and intervention.
Always assess for and address the most common triggers: bladder distention and bowel impaction.
Elevate the head of bed immediately in any patient suspected of autonomic dysreflexia.

questionTrap.trap: The question may seem straightforward, but it requires careful consideration of the underlying pathophysiology of autonomic dysreflexia and the immediate interventions needed to prevent complications.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the patient's symptoms (severe headache, elevated BP, bradycardia, diaphoresis) and prioritize interventions that address the most likely triggers and immediately lower blood pressure.

mnemonic.title: SNOOP
mnemonic.expansion: Symptoms (headache, sweating), Noxious Stimuli (bladder, bowel, skin), Observe BP, Oxygen (if needed), Pharmacology (antihypertensives)

rows: Elevate head of bed to 90 degrees
Administer a 500 mL normal saline bolus
Perform a rectal exam to check for impaction
Encourage the patient to lie flat
Decrease frequency of blood pressure monitoring to every 30 minutes
